analytic.title: This article has been accepted for inclusion in a future issue of this journal. Content is final as presented, with the exception of pagination

biblStruct.note: received November 7, 2017; revised May 10, 2018 and August 21, 2018; accepted October 7, 2018.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper presents adaptive neural tracking control of underactuated surface vessels with modeling uncertainties and time-varying external disturbances, where the tracking errors consisting of position and orientation errors are required to keep inside their predefined feasible regions in which the controller singularity problem does not happen. To provide the preselected specifications on the transient and steady-state performances of the tracking errors, the boundary functions of the predefined regions are taken as exponentially decaying functions of time. The unknown external disturbances are estimated by disturbance observers and then are compensated in the feedforward control loop to improve the robustness against the disturbances. Based on the dynamic surface control technique, backstepping procedure, logarithmic barrier functions, and control Lyapunov synthesis, singularity-free controllers are presented to guarantee the satisfaction of predefined performance requirements. In addition to the nominal case when the accurate model of a marine vessel is known a priori, the modeling uncertainties in the form of unknown nonlinear functions are also discussed. Adaptive neural control with the compensations of modeling uncertainties and external disturbances is developed to achieve the boundedness of the signals in the closed-loop system with guaranteed transient and steady-state tracking performances. Simulation results show the performance of the vessel control systems.
trajectory tracking control design problem for marine surface vessels with guaranteed transient and steady-state performances. Significant challenges to the control design mainly come from that:

1) most of surface vessels equipped with only propellers and rudders for surge and yaw motions cannot independently provide sway control force [2], which belong to a kind of underactuated systems with fewer independent actuators (inputs) than degrees of freedom (outputs) to be controlled; 2) the environmental disturbances (e.g., winds, waves, and ocean currents) inevitably affect the control systems [7]- [9]; 3) the exact knowledge of a vessel model may be unavailable for control design, e.g., hydrodynamic damping forces are hard to model accurately due to the complex maritime environments [1], [10], [11]. The external disturbances could severely influence the control system performance [12]. When modeling uncertainties are also included in the vessel dynamics, the performance deterioration might become more serious.

Many elegant model-based design techniques have been obtained for tracking control of underactuated surface vessels. Based on backstepping procedure and Lyapunov synthesis, the trajectory tracking control was presented in [13] for underactuated surface vessels. In [14], a continuous tracking controller was proposed to obtain globally uniformly ultimate boundedness (UUB), using a dynamic oscillator and nonlinear coordinate transformations. Motivated to provide robustness to uncertain parameters which appear linearly in the accurate model of the surface vessel, adaptive control approach [15], [16] was presented to solve the tracking control problem. In [15], hydrodynamic damping coefficients were assumed to be uncertain parameters and within a known compact set, and then projection algorithm was employed to estimate the unknown parameters to fulfill tracking controllers for the underactuated ship. Under the assumption that the sway velocity of the underactuated ship satisfied passivebounded condition, adaptive tracking control was presented in [16] to achieve the boundness of the closed-loop system. To compensate for modeling uncertainties in the form of nonparametric and dynamic uncertainties, recently, several elegant adaptive control techniques using neural networks (NNs) were proposed for trajectory tracking of underactuated surface vessels [17]- [20]. Using universal approximation capabilities, in [17], adaptive NN control was performed to be effective for leader-follower formation and trajectory tracking of marine surface vessels. NN-based adaptive control was developed in [18]- [20] for underactuated surface vessels in the presence of uncertain dynamics caused by hydrodynamic damping and disturbances from maritime environments.

In the above-mentioned control design techniques, a hard constraint on the tracking errors has not been addressed. The tracking error constraint means that the vessel outputs are not allowed to exceed certain constrained distance from a reference trajectory/path. Such constraint is crucial for the vessel safety and system's performance, especially in narrow waterways or in riverine applications, since any violation of the hard constraint during the vessel motions may degrade the system's performance, or may cause the controller singularity problem (see Remark 3 presented in this paper for a detailed discussion and explanation), or even cause potential collisions and system damages. Hence, the development of feedback control with state/output constraints for vessel systems is a task of major practical interest as well as theoretical significance [21], [22]. However, the number of available results by taking the constraints into account for the controller design and analysis is still limited, especially for underactuated vessels. Considering a fully actuated surface vessel with output constraints [23], an elegant adaptive control design technique was presented by employing barrier Lyapunov synthesis [24]- [29], where a barrier function with a significant feature that reaches infinity while its arguments approaching the boundaries of the constraints, was introduced in constructing a control Lyapunov function for stabilizing the control system with output constraints. Prescribed performance control (PPC) methodology originally proposed in [30] was applied in [6] and [31] for solving the problem of tracking control of a fully actuated surface vessel with time-varying output constraints, where PPC guarantees that the tracking errors stay always within the predefined regions that are bounded by the desired performance functions (typically taking as exponentially decaying functions of time). To guarantee the desired performance, the tracking errors are transformed by the use of a smooth and strictly increasing/decreasing barrier function, and then by guaranteeing Lyapunov stability for the transformed error systems, the tracking errors stay always within the predefined region. For torpedo-like and unicycle-like underactuated vehicles [32], PPC was employed to achieve UUB of the closed-loop system with prescribed performance. Under the assumption of passive-boundedness of sway velocity [16], [18], the adaptive formation control was proposed in [33] for a group of underactuated vessels, where novel tan-type barrier Lyapunov functions were employed to guarantee nonviolation of line-of-sight range and angle constraints.

Comparing with the previous works on controlling underactuated vessels [16], [18], [33], we design tracking controllers without the assumption of passive-boundedness of sway velocity. In addition, different from the time-invariant or/and symmetric output constraints [23], [24], [33], we consider asymmetric and time-dependent constraints on tracking errors. A significant feature of the time-dependent constraint is that the preselected specification on the transient and steadystate performance of tracking error (e.g., convergence rate, maximum overshoot, and steady-state error) could be established by forcing the tracking error to evolve within some predefined boundary function of time [34]- [37]. For example, the time-dependent bound is taken as an exponentially decaying function of time [32], [38]- [40], and then the convergence rate and accuracy of tracking error can be specified by appropriately setting the parameters of the exponentially decaying function. The technical contributions of this paper are summarized as follows.

1) To provide transient and steady-state performance specifications on tacking errors, the prescribed performance constraints are enforced in the control design. Two logarithmic barrier functions are employed to design tracking controllers that guarantee the satisfaction of prescribed performance requirements. Meanwhile, the proposed control design completely avoids the controller singularity problem because the tracking errors could stay always inside their feasible regions.

2) The derivatives of virtual controls include time-varying and unmeasurable terms that are hard to tackle. To avoid the calculation of the complex derivatives of virtual controls, the dynamic surface control (DSC) technique [41] is embedded in the control synthesis. In this sense, the control design yields concise controllers that are easy to realize with tractable computational complexity. 3) NN approximators are employed to approximate the uncertain vessel dynamics, and disturbance observers are presented to estimate the external disturbances and NN approximation errors. Consequently, the adaptive neural control with the compensations of modeling uncertainties and external disturbances is proposed such that all the signals in the closed-loop system remain bounded with guaranteeing the prescribed performance of tracking errors. The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section II gives the underactuated vessel model and the control objectives. Under the prescribed performance constraints on tracking errors, model-based tracking controllers are designed in Section III using the DSC technique, backstepping procedure, barrier functions, and control Lyapunov synthesis. The modeling uncertainties are considered in Section IV, and the adaptive neural control is developed to achieve the boundedness of the closed-loop system signals with guaranteeing prescribed performance. Simulation studies are performed in Section V to show the transient and steady-state performances of the control systems. Finally, the conclusion is included in Section VI.

Notation: Throughout this paper, • denotes the Euclidean norm of vectors; λ min (•) and λ max (•) denote the minimum and maximum eigenvalues of a symmetric matrix, respectively; L ∞ denotes the space of all essentially bounded functions; (ˆ) and (˜) denote the estimates of unknown parameters and estimate errors, respectively.

div.head: II. PROBLEM FORMULATION AND PRELIMINARIES
div.p: Consider an underactuated surface vessel that is equipped with one propeller and one rudder to provide a force in the surge and a torque in yaw. Assume the inertia and damping matrices are diagonal. This assumption holds for many practical vessels because most surface vessels have port/starboard and fore/aft symmetries [1]. Even for the nonsymmetry vessels, the off-diagonal terms of the system matrices are usually small compared to the main diagonal terms [42]. Following the vessel model [1], [42], the dynamic system is described by
div.formula: ẋ = u cos(ψ) -υ sin(ψ) ẏ = u sin(ψ) + υ cos(ψ) ψ = r u = m 22 m 11 υr + f u (u) + 1 m 11 τ u + 1 m 11 τ wu (t) υ = - m 11 m 22 ur + f υ (υ) + 1 m 22 τ wυ (t) ṙ = m 11 -m 22 m 33 uυ + f r (r ) + 1 m 33 τ r + 1 m 33 τ wr (t)(1)
div.p: with
div.formula: f u (u) = - d u m 11 u - 3 j =2 d u j m 11 |u| j -1 u f υ (υ) = - d υ m 22 υ - 3 j =2 d υ j m 22 |υ| j -1 υ f r (r ) = - d r m 33 r - 3 j =2 d r j m 33 |r | j -1 r (2)
div.p: where η η η = [x, y, ψ] T is the system outputs, (x, y) denotes the vessel position, and with x e = xx d and y e = yy d , and define the orientation tracking error
div.formula: ψ
ψ e = ψ -ψ d (4
div.p: where ψ d ∈ (-π, π] is the desired orientation relative to the errors x e , y e , and could be defined by [43] (

From ( 3) and ( 5), it is clear that if z e = 0, then ψ d is not well defined. Furthermore, if ψ e = ±π/2, then the control law in (34) would be singular (i.e., cos ψ e = 0, this will be further discussed later in Remark 3). To avoid the possible controller singularity problem, thus, we enforce hard constraints on the tracking errors z e and ψ e . That is, the tracking errors are required to satisfy the following conditions:
where the boundary functions e i (t) and e i (t) (i = 1, 2) are preselected such that the following inequalities hold:
It is clear that the possible controller singularity problem is avoided if the hard constraints ( 6) and ( 7) are never violated.

To provide the preselected specifications on the transient and steady-state performances of the tracking errors z e and ψ e (e.g., convergence rates, maximum overshoots, and steadystate errors), we further enforce the prescribed performance constraints in the tracking control design. Inspired by performance functions given in [30], the boundary functions e i (t) and e i (t) (i = 1, 2) are taken as the following exponentially decaying functions of time:
div.formula: ⎧ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎩ e i (t) = δ ei β i (t), i = 1, 2 e i (t) = δ ei β i (t), β i (t) = (β i0 -β i∞ )e -κ i t + β i∞ (8)
div.p: where δ ei > 0, δ ei > 0, β i0 > β i∞ > 0, κ i > 0 are preselected parameters that could be specified by designers, β i (t) is referred to as a performance function [30], and the time-varying constraints ( 6) and ( 8) on tracking errors z e and ψ e are referred to as the prescribed performance constraints. By means of the prescribed performance constraints ( 6) and ( 8), the prescribed transient and steady-state performances of tracking errors could be specified as follows: 1) the convergence speeds of the tracking errors are faster than the exponential decay rates -κ i ; 2) the lower bound of undershoots and the upper bound of overshoots are -δ ei β i0 and δ ei β i0 , respectively; and 3) the steady-state errors are within the region [-δ ei β i∞ , δ ei β i∞ ]. In addition, the transient performance with respect to the convergence rates and the maximum overshoots, and the steady-state performance with respect to the maximum allowable size of tracking errors could be improved by adjusting the preselected parameters κ i , δ ei , δ ei , β i0 , and β i∞ .

Note that the boundary functions e i (t) and e i (t) given in ( 8) are exponentially decaying functions of time, and thus their maximum values occur at the initial time t 0 (let t 0 = 0), and rely on the preselected parameters β i0 , δ ei , and δ ei . Therefore, the possible controller singularity problem is avoided completely and ψ d in ( 5) is well defined provided that the prescribed performance constraints ( 6) and ( 8) are never violated, where the preselected parameters δ ei , δ ei , and
div.formula: β i0 satisfy δ e1 β 10 < π/2, δ e1 β 10 < π/2 δ e2 < δ e2 . (9
div.p: Assumption 3: At the initial time t 0 = 0, the constrained conditions ( 6) with ( 8) hold, i.e., -π/2 < -δ e1 β 10 < ψ e (0) < δ e1 β 10 < π/2 and δ e2 β 20 < z e (0) < δ e2 β 20 .
Control Objectives: Under Assumptions 1-3, the control objective is to design feedback control laws τ u and τ r for system (1) such that:
1) all the signals in the closed-loop system are bounded;
2) the vessel position (x, y) and orientation ψ track the reference trajectory
div.formula: η η η d = [x d , y d , ψ d ] T
div.p: , and the position error z e and the orientation error ψ e converge to a small neighborhood of zero while guaranteeing nonviolation of the prescribed performance constraints ( 6) and (8).

div.head: III. CONTROL DESIGN FOR KNOWN VESSEL MODEL
div.p: In this section, we first consider the case that the exact model of the marine surface vessel is available. Under prescribed performance constraints ( 6) and ( 8), we design modelbased tracking controllers for system (1) to achieve the control objectives mentioned above. The control design is based on logarithmic barrier functions, disturbance observers, DSC technique, backstepping procedure, and Lyapunov synthesis. The DSC technique is introduced to avoid differentiating the virtual controls. The disturbance observers are used to estimate the unknown disturbances, and then the disturbances are compensated in the feedforward control loop. Thus, model-based tracking controllers with the disturbance compensations are presented to ensure the boundedness of the closed-loop system signals with guaranteeing prescribed performances.

div.head: A. Design of Yaw Moment
div.p: In this section, we apply a backstepping procedure with two steps for designing the desired yaw moment τ * r .
Step 1: Define the following errors:
div.formula: r e = r -α f r (10) y r = α f r -α r (11
div.p: where α f r is the filtered virtual control obtaining from the first-order filter ( 16), α r is the virtual control of r , and y r is the boundary layer error.

It is worth pointing out that designing a feedback controller to guarantee nonviolation of the time-varying constraint ( 6) is a challenging problem through conventional Lyapunov approach. Motivated in part by PPC methodology [30], [32], we introduce the following logarithmic barrier function:
div.formula: z 1 = 1 2 ln e 1 (t) + ψ e γ 1 (e 1 (t) -ψ e ) (12
div.p: where γ 1 = e 1 (t)/e 1 (t) and ln(•) denotes the natural logarithm. The barrier function z 1 in ( 12) owns the property of finite escape whenever the tracking error ψ e approaches the boundary of the open set (-e 1 , e 1 ) containing the origin, i.e., z 1 → ∞ as ψ e → e 1 , and
div.formula: z 1 → -∞ as ψ e → -e 1 .
div.p: Therefore, the barrier function z 1 could be used to guarantee the time-varying constraint on ψ e given in ( 6) is not violated.

In addition, it is worth noticing that the feasible set (-e 1 , e 1 ) contains the origin and the barrier function z 1 in ( 12) has an important property z 1 = 0 if and only if ψ e = 0, which means that asymptotic convergence of tracking error ψ e to the origin if the barrier function z 1 converges to an equilibrium point at the origin. However, the barrier function z 1 is not a Lyapunov function candidate since it is not positive definite. In order to obtain an everywhere nonnegative function that allows Lyapunov-based control synthesis to be developed, we define the following quadratic form of the barrier function z 1 :
whose derivative along systems (1), ( 4), ( 10), (11), and ( 12) is
div.formula: V1 = z 1 [χ 1 (α r + r e + y r -ψd ) + φ 1 ](14)
div.p: where
div.formula: χ 1 = 1 2 1 e 1 + ψ e + 1 e 1 -ψ e φ 1 = 1 2 ė1 e 1 + ψ e - ė1 e 1 -ψ e - γ1 γ 1
div.p: in which χ 1 and φ 1 are available for feedback control design. From ( 14), we design the virtual control α r as

with design parameter k z 1 > 0. To avoid the derivative of the virtual control α r , we introduce the DSC technique [41], [44], [45] in the following control development. Let α mr pass through a first-order filter with the filter time constant c 1 to obtain α f r , that is,
div.formula: c 1 α f r + α f r = α mr , α f r (0) = α mr (0) (16
div.p: where α mr = α rc 1 z 1 χ 1 and α f r are the input and output of the filters (16), respectively. It is clear from (15) that the calculation of the derivative αr is a very tricky problem. Fortunately, the derivative α f r ( α f r = -y r c 1z 1 χ 1 ) obtained from ( 11) and ( 16), instead of the derivative αr , is included in the controller (24) owing to the introduction of the DSC technique. From (16), differentiating both sides of (11) gives
where

). Remark 1: As a matter of fact, it is a very tricky problem for calculating the derivative D 1 (•) = αr . Note that D 1 (•) includes the time-varying and unmeasurable terms (sin ψ e /m 11 z e )τ wu (t) and (cos ψ e /m 22 z e )τ wυ (t) that depend explicitly on system states and external disturbances. It is worth pointing out NNs could not be directly applicable for the function approximators of such terms because the unmeasurable disturbances τ wu (t), τ wυ (t) could not be taken as NN inputs and might produce a large NN approximation error. In addition, note that the boundedness of the derivatives of the terms (sin ψ e /m 11 z e )τ wu (t) and (cos ψ e /m 22 z e )τ wυ (t) is generally unknown a priori due to the existences of z e and ψ e , and thus, the disturbance observer technique [46]- [48] could not be directly applied to estimate the unmeasurable disturbances coupled with tracking errors z e and ψ e . Therefore, how to handle such unmeasurable terms is a challenging problem. Fortunately, DSC technique [41] is introduced in our control design, without the need of virtual control differentiation, and avoids the so-called "explosion of complexity" problem [41].
Substituting the control law ( 15) into (14) gives
div.formula: V1 = -k z 1 z 2 1 + r e z 1 χ 1 + z 1 χ 1 y r (18
div.p: where the coupling terms r e z 1 χ 1 and z 1 χ 1 y r will be cancelled in the next step.
Step 2: Differentiating (10) along systems (1), (16), and (11)
div.formula: yields ṙe = m 11 -m 22 m 33 uυ + f r + 1 m 33 τ r + τ wrm + y r c 1 + z 1 χ 1 (19
div.p: where τ wrm = (1/m 33 )τ wr (t). It should be noticed that the unmeasurable disturbance τ wrm in ( 19) is unavailable for the control design. To compensate for the disturbances, motivated by the disturbance observer technique [46]- [48], we could design the following disturbance observer:
div.formula: ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ ξ1 = r e -k wr m 11 -m 22 m 33 uυ + f r + 1 m 33 τ r + τwrm + y r c 1 + z 1 χ 1 τwrm = ξ 1 + k wr r e (20
div.p: where ξ 1 is the observer state, τwrm is the estimate of τ wrm , and k wr > 0 is a design parameter. Let the observer error τwrm = τwrm -τ wrm . Consider system (19) and observer (20), the dynamics of the observer error τwrm is τwrm = r ek wr τwrm -τwrm .
Consider the following Lyapunov function candidate:
whose derivative along systems ( 17), ( 18), (19), and ( 21) is
div.formula: V * 2 = -k z 1 z 2 1 + r e z 1 χ 1 + z 1 χ 1 y r + r e × m 11 -m 22 m 33 uυ + f r + 1 m 33 τ r + τ wrm + y r c 1 + z 1 χ 1 + τwrm (r e -k wr τwrm -τwrm ) + y r - y r c 1 -z 1 χ 1 -D 1 (•) . (23
div.p: Then, the desired feedback control law τ * r could be taken as
div.formula: τ * r = m 33 -k 1 r e -2z 1 χ 1 - m 11 -m 22 m 33 uυ -f r -τwrm - y r c 1 (24
div.p: where k 1 > 0 is a design parameter. Substituting ( 24) into ( 23) gives
div.formula: V * 2 = -k z 1 z 2 1 -k 1 r 2 e -k wr τ 2 wrm - y 2 r c 1 -τwrm τwrm -y r D 1 (•).(25)

div.head: B. Design of Surge Force
div.p: In this section, we construct the desired surge force τ * u using the backstepping procedure with two steps.
Step 1: From (3) and (5), we have Define the following errors:
div.formula: u e = u -α f u (28
y u = α f u -α u (29
div.p: where α f u is the filtered virtual control, α u is the virtual control of u, and y u is the boundary layer error. To handle the time-varying constraint on tracking error z e given in (6), we consider the following barrier function:
div.formula: z 2 = 1 2 ln e 2 (t) -z e γ 2 (z e -e 2 (t)) (30
div.p: with γ 2 = e 2 (t)/e 2 (t). Remark 2: Similar to the barrier function z 1 in (12), z 2 in (30) is also a barrier function, i.e., z 2 → ∞ as z e → e 2 , and z 2 → -∞ as z e → e 2 . The barrier function z 2 is employed to guarantee the error z e keeps inside the feasible set (e 2 , e 2 ), in which ψ d defined in ( 5) is always well defined (i.e., z e = 0).
The derivative of z 2 along system ( 27) is
div.formula: ż2 = χ 2 (u cos ψ e -υ sin ψ e -ẋd cos ψ d -ẏd sin ψ d ) + φ 2 (31
div.p: where
div.formula: χ 2 = 1 2 1 z e -e 2 + 1 e 2 -z e φ 2 = 1 2 ė2 e 2 -z e + ė2 z e -e 2 - γ2 γ 2 .
div.p: Consider the following Lyapunov function candidate:
whose derivative along systems ( 31), (28), and ( 29) is
div.formula: V3 = z 2 [χ 2 ((α u + y u + u e ) cos ψ e -υ sin ψ e -ẋd cos ψ d -ẏd sin ψ d ) + φ 2 ].(33)
div.p: Thus, we design the virtual control α u as follows:
div.formula: α u = 1 cos ψ e -χ -1 2 (k z 2 z 2 + φ 2 ) + υ sin ψ e + ẋd cos ψ d + ẏd sin ψ d (34
div.p: where k z 2 > 0 is a design parameter. Similar to ( 16), the firstorder filter with filter time constant c 2 is given by
div.formula: c 2 α f u + α f u = α mu , α f u (0) = α mu (0) (35
div.p: with α mu = α uc 2 z 2 χ 2 cos ψ e . Differentiating (29) and using (35) give
div.formula: ẏu = - y u c 2 -z 2 χ 2 cos ψ e -D 2 (•)(36)
div.p: where

Remark 3: To stabilize the dynamic system (31), the velocities u and υ could be taken as the virtual control inputs for a fully actuated surface vessel [6], [23], [31], while for an underactuated surface vessel only u is taken as the virtual control input due to the fact that there is no independent actuator in the sway direction. Thus, cos ψ e can be viewed as the control gain of system (31). If the feedback linearizationtype controller (34) is considered, a difficulty arises when cos ψ e → 0, which is referred to the controller singularity problem. Additional precautions should be made for avoiding the possible singularity problem because standard control laws [15], [16], [49], [50] do not guarantee cos ψ e being away from zero. To handle such a problem, we enforce the predefined constraint (6) satisfying ( 8) and (9), where the orientation error is required to keep inside the feasible set (-(π/2), (π/2)) in which the singularity problem does not happen. To provide the preselected specifications on the transient and steady-state performances of the tracking errors, we further enforce the prescribed performance constraint ( 6) with ( 8) and ( 9) in our control design. We apply the barrier Lyapunov function approach to design tracking controllers such that the tracking errors always keep inside the predefined sets that are bounded by exponentially decaying functions, and thus cos ψ e is guaranteed to be away from zero.
Step 2: Differentiating (28) along systems ( 1) and ( 35 (39) with k wu > 0 being a design parameter. Let the observer error τwum = τwum -τ wum . From system (38) and observer (39), we have
div.formula: τwum = u e -k wu τwum -τwum . (40
div.p: Consider the following Lyapunov function candidate:
whose derivative along systems ( 36), ( 37), (38), and ( 40) is
div.formula: V * 4 = -k z 2 z 2 2 + u e z
+ y u - y u c 2 -z 2 χ 2 cos ψ e -D 2 (•) . (42
div.p: Then, the desired control input τ * u could be taken as
div.formula: τ * u = m 11 -k 2 u e - m 22 m 11 υr -f u -τwum - y u c 2 -2z 2 χ 2 cos ψ e (43
div.p: where k 2 > 0 is a design parameter. Substituting the control law ( 43) into (42) gives
div.formula: V * 4 = -k z 2 z 2 2 -k 2 u 2 e -k wu τ 2 wum - y 2 u c 2 -τwum τwum -y u D 2 (•). (44

div.head: C. Stability Analysis
div.p: This section is devoted to the stability analysis of the closedloop system through the Lyapunov stability theory.
Consider the following Lyapunov function candidate:
whose derivative is
div.formula: V * = -k z 1 z 2 1 -k 1 r 2 e -k wr τ 2 wrm - y 2 r c 1 -k z 2 z 2 2 -k 2 u 2 e -k wu τ 2 wum - y 2 u c 2 -τwrm τwrm -y r D 1 (•) -τwum τwum -y u D 2 (•)
div.p: according to (25)
div.formula: -y r D 1 (•) ≤ κy 2 r 2 + D2 1 2κ -y u D 2 (•) ≤ κy 2 u 2 + D2
div.p: 2 2κ with constants κ > 0, τwrm > 0, and τwum > 0, where τwrm and τwum denote the upper bounds of τwrm and τwum , respectively. Then, we could obtain
where
div.formula: ρ * = min 2k z1 , 2k 1 , 2k wr -κ, 2 c 1 -κ, 2k z 2 , 2k 2 , 2k wu -κ, 2 c 2 -κ δ * = 1 2κ τ 2 wrm + τ 2 wum + D2 1 + D2 2 .
div.p: It follows from ( 46) that choosing ρ * > δ * /ς yields V * ≤ 0 on V * = ς which indicates that V * ≤ ς is an invariant, that is, if V * (0) ≤ ς , then V * (t) ≤ ς for all t > 0. Thus, we have the following UUB result for the closed-loop error systems. Lemma 1: Under Assumptions 1-3, consider the closedloop system consisting of plant (1), control laws ( 24) and (43), and disturbance observers (20) and (39). If given any ς > 0 for all initial conditions satisfying V * (0) ≤ ς , and the preselected parameters satisfying (9), then there exist design parameters

such that V * (t) ≤ ς , ∀t > 0, and V * ≤ -ρ * V * + δ * hold, which mean that: 1) the errors z 1 , r e , y r , z 2 , u e , y u , and the disturbance observer errors ( τwrm , τwum ) are uniformly ultimately bounded; 2) the errors z 1 , r e , y r , z 2 , u e , y u , and the disturbance observer errors ( τwrm , τwum ) converge to an adjustable neighborhood of the origin by appropriately choosing the design parameters. Proof: From inequality (46), we have
where * = (δ * /ρ * ). Substituting ( 45) into (48) yields
div.formula: 1 2 z 2 1 + r 2 e + τ 2 wrm + y 2 r + z 2 2 + u 2 e + τ 2 wum + y 2 u ≤ V * (0) exp(-ρ * t) + * (49)
div.p: which implies that as t approaches infinity, the following inequalities

, and |y u | ≤ √ 2 * hold. Therefore, the errors z 1 , r e , y r , z 2 , u e , y u , τwrm , and τwum are uniformly ultimately bounded and converge exponentially to a small residual set √ 2 * , and the size of the residual set √ 2 * could be adjusted by appropriately choosing the design parameters.

Form ( 12) and ( 30), it follows that the boundedness of z 1 and z 2 means the errors ψ e and z e are also bounded. Using (3), ( 4), and Assumption 2, it is clear that x e , y e , ψ, x, and y are bounded. From Assumption 1, we can conclude that τwrm and τwum are also bounded since τwrm and τwum are bounded. From ( 10), (11), and ( 15), we have r , α f r , and α r are bounded. In what follows, we will show that υ is also bounded. Using system (1) with ( 2), ( 28), ( 29), (34), the sway velocity dynamics could be rewritten as

div.p: are bounded according to Lemma 1 and Assumptions 1-2. Note that the system parameters d υ3 , d υ2 , and m 22 are positive constants. Now, we present the following lemma to show that the sway velocity υ given in ( 50) is bounded. Lemma 2: Consider system (50) with Assumption 1 and the system parameters m 22 > 0, d υ3 > 0, and d υ2 > 0. If the boundedness of b 0 and b 1 given in ( 51) and ( 52) is guaranteed, then the vessel sway velocity υ is bounded.
Proof: Consider the following Lyapunov function candidate: 53) IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON NEURAL NETWORKS AND LEARNING SYSTEMS whose derivative along system ( 50) is
where

div.p: )/(2b 2 ) holds when t goes to infinity. Thus, the vessel velocity υ is bounded.
Next, we present model-based tracking controllers for underactuated system (1) that achieves the boundedness of the closed-loop system with prescribed performance guarantees.

Theorem 1: Under Assumptions 1-3, consider the underactuated vessel system (1) for which the model dynamics is obtained for the control design, model-based tracking controllers ( 24), (43), and disturbance observers (20), (39). If given any ς > 0 for all initial conditions satisfying V * (0) ≤ ς , and the design parameters satisfy ( 9) and ( 47), then we have:

1) all the signals in the closed-loop system are bounded; 2) the tracking errors (z e , ψ e ) exponentially converge to an adjustable neighborhood of the equilibrium point ((2δ e2 δ e2 β 2∞ )/(δ e2 + δ e2 ), 0) while guaranteeing nonviolation of the prescribed performance constraints ( 6) and ( 8). Proof: 1) From Lemma 1, we can conclude that the errors z 1 , r e , y r , z 2 , u e , y u , and the disturbance observer errors ( τwrm , τwum ) are uniformly ultimately bounded and converge exponentially to a small neighborhood of zero. Using Assumption 2, we know that the system states x, y, and ψ are bounded. The boundedness of virtual control α r is guaranteed by (15) and Assumption 2, which implies that r is also bounded. Thus, b 0 and b 1 given in ( 51) and ( 52) are bounded, which means that υ is also bounded by Lemma 2. Using (34), the boundedness of υ means that α u is bounded, which further yields the surge velocity u bounded. Subsequently, τwrm and τwum are bounded due to the boundedness of τwrm and τwum , respectively. Therefore, the control inputs given in (24) and (43) are bounded since all the signals included in the control laws are bounded.
2) From ( 12) and ( 30), we could obtain

div.head: IV. CONTROL DESIGN FOR MODELING UNCERTAINTIES
div.p: In this section, we deal with scenarios wherein modeling uncertainties (or modeling errors) are presented in system (1). We design an adaptive neural control for system (1) to ensure the boundedness of the closed-loop system with guaranteed nonviolation of the time-varying constraint ( 6) with ( 8) and (9). We consider the following model uncertainties.

Assumption 4: Considering the underactuated vessel system (1) with hydrodynamic damping term (2). The hydrodynamic damping terms given in (2) are continuous nonlinear functions of vehicle velocities, and they are partially known and represent modeling uncertainties of the vessel system (1).

Under Assumption 4, the desired control laws τ * r and τ * u given in (24) and (43), and the disturbance observers given in (20) and ( 39) cannot be implemented, in practice, because they include the uncertain terms f r and f u , respectively. To tackle the modeling uncertainties and external disturbances, in this section, we use NNs to approximate the uncertain damping terms f r , f u , and present the disturbance observers to estimate the unknown disturbances. Using the universal approximation of Gaussian radial basis function (RBF) NNs [52]- [54], the continuous functions f r and f u given in (2) could be approximated to any accuracy, which can be represented as follows:

where Z i , i = 1, 2 are the NN input vectors, W * i are ideal constant weight vectors that are unknown, S i (Z i ) and i (Z i ) are, respectively, the RBF vectors and the approximation errors which could be bounded by the constants s * i > 0 and

V ≤ -ρV + δ (75) in which ρ = min 2k z1 , 2k 3 -κ, k dr -κ, 2 c 1 -κ, 2k z 2 , 2k 4 -κ, k du -κ, 2 c 2 -κ δ = D2 1 + D2 2 2κ + w * 2 1 s * 2 1 + w * 2 2 s * 2 2 + d2 wr + d2 wu 2 κ + k dr w * 2 1 s * 2 1 + k du w * 2 2 s * 2 2 2 .
div.p: The following theorem gives the tracking results of adaptive neural control of underactuated surface vessels with modeling uncertainties, external disturbances, and prescribed performance constraints.

Theorem 2: Consider underactuated surface vessel (1) and ( 2) satisfying Assumptions 1-4, control laws τ r in (66) and τ u in (67), disturbance observers (61) and (64), and NN weights Z 2 for all t ≥ 0. If given any ς > 0 for all initial conditions satisfying V (0) ≤ ς with the preselected parameters satisfing (9), and the design parameters satisfy

then we have: 1) all the signals in the closed-loop system remain bounded; 2) the tracking errors (z e , ψ e ) exponentially converge to an adjustable neighborhood of the equilibrium point ((2δ e2 δ e2 β 2∞ )/(δ e2 + δ e2 ), 0), and the observer errors ( dwr , dwu ) converge to an adjustable neighborhood of the origin by appropriately choosing the design parameters; 3) the prescribed performance constraints ( 6) and ( 8) are never violated. Proof: The proof is similar to that of Theorem 1 and is therefore omitted.

div.head: V. SIMULATION STUDIES
div.p: To show the performance of the proposed tracking controllers, we preform numerical simulation on a monohull surface vessel equipping with one propeller and one rudder. The length of the vessel is 38 m with a mass of 118 × 10 3 kg, and other system parameters in International System of Units obtained from [42] are given in Table I. Without loss of generality, the unmeasurable environmental disturbances are given by τ τ τ w = M[1.5 + sin(0.1t) + cos(0.01t), 1.5 + cos(0.1t) + sin(0.01t), 1.5sin(0.1t) + cos(0.

Here, the control objective is to make the vessel position and orientation track the reference trajectory consisting of (76) and ( 5) while guaranteeing the prescribed transient and steadystate performances of tracking errors ψ e and z e specified by the performance function (77). In the following, simulation studies are conducted for two cases: 1) accurate vessel model is available, i.e., the hydrodynamic damping effects f u , f υ , and f r defined in (2) are accurately known; and 2) the nonlinear functions f u , f υ , and f r are uncertain dynamics.

Model-Based Control: We first consider the case that accurate vessel model is obtained a priori. Model-based controllers (MBCs) given in (24) and (43) with disturbance observers (20) and ( 39) are applied to system (1) to attain the tracking control objective. The design parameters are taken as

Adaptive Neural Control: We consider the case that system (1) suffers from unknown external disturbances and modeling uncertainties. We apply adaptive controllers (66) and (67) with NN weight updating laws (68), (69), and disturbance observers (61), (64) to achieve the control objective. The design parameters are given by Simulation results for both MBC and adaptive neural controller (ANC) are shown in Figs. 123. The tracking results in Fig. 1 show that both MBC and ANC could force the vessel position (x, y) of system (1) to follow the desired trajectory (x d , y d ) with a satisfactory tracking performance. The tracking results shown in Fig. 2(a) indicate that the orientation errors ψ e of the two controllers evolve within the predefined region bounded by the performance functions e 1 (t) and -e 1 (t) given in (77). Fig. 2(b) represents the evolutions of position errors z e of the two controllers and illustrates that the position errors z e do not violate the prescribed performance constraints for both controllers. The control inputs of the two controllers are shown in Fig. 3(a) and (b). Compared with the tracking errors in Fig. 2(a) and (b), and the control inputs shown in Fig. 3(a) and (b), there exist larger tracking errors and larger oscillations of control inputs in the adaptive control systems. This is mainly because less a priori knowledge for the vessel plant is obtained, and then the adaptive controllers need to tune their NN weights online to adapt to the modeling uncertainties. It should be emphasized that the prescribed transient and steady-state tracking performances for system (1) are achieved using ANC, as shown in Fig. 2(a) and (b), even though there exist both the modeling uncertainties and external disturbances acting on the vessel control system.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: This paper proposed the trajectory tacking control of underactuated surface vessels with modeling uncertainties and time-varying external disturbances. Using logarithmic barrier functions, disturbance observers, DSC technique, and control Lyapunov synthesis, model-based tracking controllers were designed such that the tracking errors stay always within certain predefined time-varying bounds. Meanwhile, the proposed control design completely avoided the possible singularity problem. NN approximators were employed to approximate uncertain vessel dynamics, and disturbance observers were proposed to estimate the unknown disturbances. Consequently, the adaptive neural control with uncertainty and disturbance compensations was developed to achieve the boundedness of the signals in the closed-loop system with guaranteed transient and steady-state tracking performances.

The reference signals x d and y d are generated by the following dynamic equation: ẋd = u d cos(r d t) ẏd = υ d sin(r d t) (76) with x d (0) = 0 and y d (0) = 0. In the simulation, we set u d = 5, υ d = 6, and r d = 0.05, which implies that the reference trajectory is an ellipse with major axis 120 m and minor axis 100 m. The desired orientation ψ d is given in (5). The initial states of the vessel are [x(0), y(0), ψ(0)] T = [0, 20, 0.6] T and [u(0), υ(0), r (0)] T = [0, 0, 0] T .
